items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:45pm and 1:45am today, Tuesday 25th and into tomorrow, Wednesday 26th October.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.79 mAODN at 12:45am, on Wednesday 26th October, which is 0.16m above tide tables, wind Force 5, south easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 26th October.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:15 PM (BST) on 26/10/2022.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. No property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. 
This message will be updated in the afternoon on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:15 PM (BST) on 26/10/2022.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss.
No property flooding is expected. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. 
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We will continue to monitor the forecast.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. 
This message will be updated in the afternoon on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of the forecast weather conditions during spring tides tomorrow afternoon, 26/10/2022. Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland, is expected between 1 pm and 02:15 pm on 26/10/2022 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 1 pm, and 1:45 pm, Eastford Road, between 1:15 pm, and 2 pm, and Arpley Bridge, between 1:30 pm, and 2:15 pm. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 4 pm tomorrow 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:15 PM on 26/10/2022.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences in low lying areas and flooding is possible around Ulverston and Sandside between 10:15 AM and 02:15 PM on 26/10/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been as strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, Wednesday 26/10/2022. The particular area at risk is around Kilnsea village. Flooding of low lying land and coastal roads is possible between 6 AM and 9 AM on Wednesday 26/10/2022. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This alert may also need to be in force for high tides on Thursday 27/10/2022 and Friday 28/10/2022. This message will be updated by 1 PM on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued as strong winds and unsettled weather may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning, Wednesday 26/10/2022. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Kilnsea Caravan Park, Southfield Farm coastal side and Spurn Road. Flooding of low lying land and coastal roads is possible between 5:30 AM and 8:30 AM on Wednesday 26/10/2022. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This alert may also need to be in force for high tides on Thursday 27/10/2022 and Friday 28/10/2022. This message will be updated by 1 PM on Wednesday, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.62mAOD at 15:30 on 25/10/22 and 4.68mAOD at 03:45 on 26/10/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 58 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/10/22, or as the situation changes.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. 
The first forecast high water is at 09:45 PM on Tuesday 25/10/2022 with a level of 1.24mAODN with southerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 09:45 AM on Wednesday 26/10/2022 with a level of 1.39mAODN with south-easterly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of these times.
We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Christchurch Harbour.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The forecast for tonight, 25/10/22, is mostly dry with some lighter rain showers possible in the early hours. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Middle Level of the Fens in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from the recent rainfall has now reduced. We will continue to monitor the situation and provide an update if appropriate.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The forecast for today is mostly dry with some lighter rain showers possible this afternoon and overnight.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Falmouth is at 5.08pm Tuesday and 6.18am Wednesday, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong force 6 south and south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas.  

Expect tides to be up to 400mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

A large tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 07:30 and 09:00 tomorrow morning, 26/10/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.6m at 08:30 on 26/10, Newport 7.0m to 7.3m at 08:15 on 26/10   
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 26/10/22 by 10:00, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle at 10:00 AM on 26/10/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in the Poole Harbour area.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 07:15 AM on 26/10/2022.
Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.
The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at West Bay Harbour. The forecast high water is at 07:15 AM on 26/10/2022 with a level of 2.53 mAODN with southerly force 6 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 7.45pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Strong force 6 south easterly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 260mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.35 mAOD, this is 0.26 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday morning. High water at Ilfracombe is at 7.15am, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Strong force 6 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 410mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.01 mAOD, this is 0.41 metres above astronomical tide level.

This Flood Alert for Newbiggin Bay Promenade (north) has now been removed. There is no longer risk to beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as wave overtopping and spray has reduced. We continue to monitor the situation.
This Flood Alert for Berwick Between Bridges has now been removed. There is no longer risk to areas by the estuary as wave overtopping and spray has reduced. We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:15 PM (BST) on 26/10/2022.
Flooding is possible at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss from 10:30 AM on 26/10/2022.
No property flooding is expected.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated in the afternoon on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message: A combination of strong winds and spring tides may cause waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow afternoon between 12:00 noon and 1:30 PM on 26/10/2022. Waves are forecast to affect coastal low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall. The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal, but we are not anticipating any further issues at this location. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 3pm tomorrow 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:45 PM on 26/10/2022 at Port Carlisle.
Flooding is possible along sections of coastline from Gretna to Silloth between 10:45 AM and 02:45 PM on 26/10/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of a tidal surge coinciding with high river levels.  The next high tides at Torksey will be at 22:15 on 25/10/22 and 10:00 on 26/10/22.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon on 26/10/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
 This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/10/22, or as the situation changes.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:04 and 14:24 on 26/10/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.38 m. The total forecast tide is 4.29 metres Chart Datum (2.29 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood the garden of the Mill House on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. It will also flow across Palace Lane and the B3056 (Hatchet Lane), making it temporarily more difficult for traffic to access the village. Flood water in Palace Lane could be up to 0.2m deep. After this tide, the weather becomes more settled, so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. For safety, please take care if walking through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood roads quickly. At Hatchet Lane, driving through flood water increases flood risk to property. Please avoid using this road. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 26/10/2022

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:30 on 26/10/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, although flood depths will be relatively shallow, and flooding will only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. After this tide, the weather becomes more settled, so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond in the morning ahead of the high tide. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 26/10/2022

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 26/10/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.38 m. The total forecast tide is 4.77 metres Chart Datum (2.18 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impact flooding will affect some sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island. Water will be high up slipways in Cowes, affecting Medina Road and the Floating Bridge. In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains may cause very minor impacts to the road at Albany Road. After this tide, the weather becomes more settled, so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. At Medina Road, near the Floating Bridge, the tide may rise to be only 0.1m below the top of front door steps. As a precautionary measure, and if you have it, we recommend that flood protection is installed at Medina Road 1 hour before high tide. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 26/10/2022

Wednesday afternoon's high tide at 12:04 and 14:24 on 26/10/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.38 m. The total forecast tide is 5.22 metres Chart Datum (2.48 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impacts of flooding will affect the lower floor level of Eling Tide Mill and boat yards at Bursledon. Road and car park flooding may occur at The Quay Hamble, Magazine Lane at Marchwood and Shore Road in Hythe. After this tide, the weather becomes more settled, so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. Avoid parking in low lying coastal car parks and plan driving routes to avoid the roads listed above. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 26/10/2022

The tide on Wednesday lunchtime will be higher than normal due to unsettled conditions, increasing the river levels in the Lower River Itchen at Mansbridge. The Southampton high tide at 12:00 on Wednesday 26/10/2022 is forecast at 5.22 metres Chart Datum (2.48 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing to sea. This may cause the river to flood the access road and affect the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may also affect Riverside Park. With only light rain forecast and reducing tide levels, further impacts are not expected. We recommend closing the defence gates around the White Swan pub at least an hour before high tide. We will monitor the situation and open the sea door at Woodmill on Wednesday morning to help lower river levels. Given that the situation is expected to improve, we will remove this Flood Alert by 18:00 on 26/10/2022.
